R.0. T. C. Work Progressing.

The activities of the R. 0. T. C.
are now well under way. Captain
Guild has announced that Prof.
C. J. Tilde, of the Civil Engineering Department, has offered
to give all the help in his power
to those taking the military engineering work.
There are now about five groups.
taking this advanced work. One
is constructing a complete model
of a camp kitchen, another is
building an incinerator, a third a
hot-water boiler, while the others
are working on other sanitary devices. These models, when completed, will be placed on exhibition
in the military laboratory on the
fourth floor of Gilman Hall, as
an example of what can be done
with materials that are readily
obtainable by the students.
The second-year men are continuing their study of topography,
their work being largely indoor at
present. They have studied the
uses of the slide rule, the making
of scales, and the reading of
maps.
Those first-year men who are
very proficient in their drilling
are working on the relief map
problems. These maps are constructed in sections on a large
scale, so that they may be arranged in a great number of combinations. The various men of the
groups place colored pins in different positions on these maps,
showing how they would effect
protection against attack for
troops on the march.

The hardest football schedule
every undertaken by a Hopkins
team is practically completed. The
northern teams which have been
scheduled and the Navy game will
be an opportunity for Coach Murphy to give Hopkins a rating
which will put it in a class higher
than it has heretofore filled.
Should the game with the University of Virginia be arranged, it
is expected that it will become a
yearly affair of great interest, for
both teams have many supporters in and around Baltimore.
Coach Murphy is about to institute spring football practice for
those men who are not on other
'Varsity teams. Such training will
be of great value in shaping new
material, and getting all old men
returned from the service accustomed again to handling the pigskin. TheY team will practice under the- direct supervision of
Coach Murphy, who expects to try
a lot of new men for the various
positions open.
Of the letter men of 1917, Captain Jones, Stanley, Hecht, Calkins and other are back, while
Stewart, Stearns, Gould and many
other men either have H. A. A.'s
or have had previous experience.

Round Table Club Organizes.

The organization meeting of the
Round Table Group for the discussion of current social problems
was held last Thursday night in
the Barn. Henry E. Niles was
elected chairman and it was decided that the club hold its meetings down -town on Thursday
nights from 8 to 9.30. The club's
purpose is to study current social
and political topics without partiality to any school of thought.
The leader of the group is Dr.
Richard W. Hogue, of the Prisoners' Aid Association. Dr. Hogue
is interested in the problems of
reconstruction and is in close
touch with local industrial conditions. All students of the University who are interested are invited to join this study group.
Notice of the place of the next
meeting will be placed on the bulletin board in the postoffice.

Military Organization Formed.

Enthusiastic over the success
which the night course in military training has attained, the
students and alumni of the Hopkins School of Military Art organized a military institution,
which they hope will in a short
time rival the Richmond Blues
and the New York Old Guard, at
a dinner given at the Baltimore
Athletic Association last Saturday night.
Announcement was made at the
dinner that a uniform for the organization has already been decided upon and is now being made.
Arrangements have also been
made to use the Fifth Regiment
Veteran Corps Hall, on Madison
avenue, for drilling purposes until permanent headquarters of
their own can be secured.
Among the speakers were „Major George W. Hyde, Captains E.
A. Watts, E. W. Wonderly, J. W.
Leland and William H. Thomas,
Jr. The following officers were
elected for the new organization:
William Biedler, president;
William H. Lawrence, vice-president; Charles B. Dieffenderfer,
treasurer, and L. W. Bullard, secretary.

Declaring against the highly
paid athletic coach in American
universities, editors of three college dailies—the Harvard Crimson, the Princeton Princetonian
and the Yale Daily News—adopted resolutions at a meeting outlining the policy of the papers toward college athletics.
The college dailies will advocate
the hiring of an all-year-around
coach by each university, with assistants in various branches, but
eliminating the specialist who
coaches one team for a few
months. These papers will also
advocate the formation of a Department of Physical Training in
each college, with rigid physical
examinations for all entering students.

Hopkins Men Eligible to Win Thousand Dollars—Subjects Given.

The National Industrial Conference Board has offered a prize of
4;1,000 for the best monograph on
any one of the following subjects:
• 1. A practicable plan for representation of workers in determining conditions of work and for
prevention of industrial disputes.
2. The major causes of unemployment and hqw to minimize
them.
3. How can efficiency of workers be so increased as to make high
wage rates economically practicable?
4. Should the State interfere
in the determination of wage
rates?
5. Should rates of wages be
definitely based on the cost living?
6. How can present systems of
wage payments be so perfected and
supplemented as to be most conducive to individual efficiency and
to the contentment of workers?
7. The closed union shop versus
the open shop: their social and
economic value compared.
8. Should trade unions and employers' associations be made legally responsible?
The contest is open without restriction to all persons except
those who are members of or identified with the National Industrial Conference Board.
Contestants are not limited to
papers of any length, but they
should not be unduly expanded.
Especial weight will be given to
English and to skill in exposition.
The copyright of the prize manuscript, with.all publication rights,
will be vested in the National Industrial Conference Board.
Each competitor should sign his
manuscript with an assumed name,
sending his true name and address
in a sealed envelope superscribed
with his assumed name. No manuscript will be .accepted the real
authorship of which is disclosed
when the manuscript is received
by the Board, nor any which has
been previously published in any
way.
Manuscripts, to be considered in
the contest, must be mailed on or
before July 1, 1919, to the National Industrial Conference Board,15
Beacon street, Boston, Mass.,
marked "For Prize Essay Contest
in Industrial Economics."

To the Editor of THE NEws-LErrER:

Sir—The practice of smoking in
the various classrooms ought to
be stopped by student opinion,
just as the behavior of men is
governed by public opinion. THE
NEWS-LETTER should initiate a
campaign against this "promiscuous" smoking in the academic
classrooms and corridors. Several
members of the faculty have indirectly signified that they look
upon it as highly undesirable.
This year is the first time that
there has been so much smoking
about the buildings to attract the
attention and critieism of anyone
of the faculty. It is a poor precedent, and if students are allowed
to go unchecked, smoking about
the buildings will become an objectionable tradition that* will be
hard to eradicate.

The activities of the R. 0. T. C.
are now well under way. Captain
Guild has announced that Prof.
C. J. Tilde, of the Civil Engineering Department, has offered
to give all the help in his power
to those taking the military engineering work.
There are now about five groups.
taking this advanced work. One
is constructing a complete model
of a camp kitchen, another is
building an incinerator, a third a
hot-water boiler, while the others
are working on other sanitary devices. These models, when completed, will be placed on exhibition
in the military laboratory on the
fourth floor of Gilman Hall, as
an example of what can be done
with materials that are readily
obtainable by the students.
The second-year men are continuing their study of topography,
their work being largely indoor at
present. They have studied the
uses of the slide rule, the making
of scales, and the reading of
maps.
Those first-year men who are
very proficient in their drilling
are working on the relief map
problems. These maps are constructed in sections on a large
scale, so that they may be arranged in a great number of combinations. The various men of the
groups place colored pins in different positions on these maps,
showing how they would effect
protection against attack for
troops on the march.

every undertaken by a Hopkins
team is practically completed. The
northern teams which have been
scheduled and the Navy game will
be an opportunity for Coach Murphy to give Hopkins a rating

yearly affair of great interest, for
both teams have many supporters in and around Baltimore.

material, and getting all old men

a lot of new men for the various
positions open.

Round Table Club Organizes.

The organization meeting of the
Round Table Group for the discussion of current social problems
was held last Thursday night in
the Barn. Henry E. Niles was
elected chairman and it was decided that the club hold its meetings down -town on Thursday
nights from 8 to 9.30. The club's
purpose is to study current social
and political topics without partiality to any school of thought.
The leader of the group is Dr.
Richard W. Hogue, of the Prisoners' Aid Association. Dr. Hogue
is interested in the problems of
reconstruction and is in close
touch with local industrial conditions. All students of the University who are interested are invited to join this study group.
Notice of the place of the next
meeting will be placed on the bulletin board in the postoffice.

Military Organization Formed.

Enthusiastic over the success
which the night course in military training has attained, the
students and alumni of the Hopkins School of Military Art organized a military institution,
which they hope will in a short
time rival the Richmond Blues
and the New York Old Guard, at
a dinner given at the Baltimore
Athletic Association last Saturday night.
Announcement was made at the
dinner that a uniform for the organization has already been decided upon and is now being made.
Arrangements have also been
made to use the Fifth Regiment
Veteran Corps Hall, on Madison
avenue, for drilling purposes until permanent headquarters of
their own can be secured.
Among the speakers were „Major George W. Hyde, Captains E.
A. Watts, E. W. Wonderly, J. W.
Leland and William H. Thomas,
Jr. The following officers were
elected for the new organization:
William Biedler, president;
William H. Lawrence, vice-president; Charles B. Dieffenderfer,
treasurer, and L. W. Bullard, secretary.

Declaring against the highly
paid athletic coach in American
universities, editors of three college dailies—the Harvard Crimson, the Princeton Princetonian
and the Yale Daily News—adopted resolutions at a meeting outlining the policy of the papers toward college athletics.
The college dailies will advocate
the hiring of an all-year-around
coach by each university, with assistants in various branches, but
eliminating the specialist who
coaches one team for a few
months. These papers will also
advocate the formation of a Department of Physical Training in
each college, with rigid physical
examinations for all entering students.

Hopkins Men Eligible to Win Thousand Dollars—Subjects Given.

The National Industrial Conference Board has offered a prize of
4;1,000 for the best monograph on
any one of the following subjects:
• 1. A practicable plan for representation of workers in determining conditions of work and for
prevention of industrial disputes.
2. The major causes of unemployment and hqw to minimize
them.
3. How can efficiency of workers be so increased as to make high
wage rates economically practicable?
4. Should the State interfere
in the determination of wage
rates?
5. Should rates of wages be
definitely based on the cost living?
6. How can present systems of
wage payments be so perfected and
supplemented as to be most conducive to individual efficiency and
to the contentment of workers?
7. The closed union shop versus
the open shop: their social and
economic value compared.
8. Should trade unions and employers' associations be made legally responsible?
The contest is open without restriction to all persons except
those who are members of or identified with the National Industrial Conference Board.
Contestants are not limited to
papers of any length, but they
should not be unduly expanded.
Especial weight will be given to
English and to skill in exposition.
The copyright of the prize manuscript, with.all publication rights,
will be vested in the National Industrial Conference Board.
Each competitor should sign his
manuscript with an assumed name,
sending his true name and address
in a sealed envelope superscribed
with his assumed name. No manuscript will be .accepted the real
authorship of which is disclosed
when the manuscript is received
by the Board, nor any which has
been previously published in any
way.
Manuscripts, to be considered in
the contest, must be mailed on or
before July 1, 1919, to the National Industrial Conference Board,15
Beacon street, Boston, Mass.,
marked "For Prize Essay Contest
in Industrial Economics."

Opposes Smoking In Class-rooms.
To the Editor of THE NEws-LErrER:

Sir—The practice of smoking in
the various classrooms ought to
be stopped by student opinion,
just as the behavior of men is
governed by public opinion. THE
NEWS-LETTER should initiate a
campaign against this "promiscuous" smoking in the academic
classrooms and corridors. Several
members of the faculty have indirectly signified that they look
upon it as highly undesirable.
This year is the first time that
there has been so much smoking
about the buildings to attract the
attention and critieism of anyone
of the faculty. It is a poor precedent, and if students are allowed
to go unchecked, smoking about
the buildings will become an objectionable tradition that* will be
hard to eradicate.

basket-ball team playing under the
name of Hopkins, or even as an independent team. Coach Murphy

put through a good schedule, to
say nothing of organizing a team
which could fairly represent Hopkins.

to continue to practice basket-ball,
the balloon shed may be used on

expected that in the fall a fast

game are very bright, for if the
basket-ball league of the S. A. I.

the present plans, a schedule will
be arranged which will include
most of the large colleges in the

The Freshman-Sophomore track
meet will take place on March 7,in
the cage. Both classes will be well
represented and the meet promises
to be an exciting one. The Sophomores have, of course, had more
experience than the wearers of
the green, but the latter have several very good men who are developing into speedy runners. Among
these are Norwood, Frank, King,
Barret and Blakiston.
The Sophomores, besides being
more experienced, are also more
numerous. They include Van
Ness, a letter man, Heiner, Lord,
Niles, Biemiller and Hazeltine.
The men are practicing daily on
Straus Field, their locker rooms
having been recently transferred
to Homewood Field.

the Charcoal Club about three
